item.title: Can't figure it out. Help please
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“abraham2119, post:7, topic:355612”]Don’t listen to Davidi2, he’s a clueless moron.

The thing with your current design is your use of OOP is kind of flawed. What you should have is the main class reading the next two numbers and then performing the required arithmetic operation, instead of simply pasting the same exact code in each one of the operation classes. Regardless, the operation handling can be setup in a map holding a character as the key (the operation character) and the selected handler as the value.

I wrote up an example that should be easy for you to understand of what the application should be:

import java.io.Console;
import java.util.HashMap;

class Main {

	public static void main(String[] args) {
		Console console = System.console();
		ArithmeticOperation operation = null;
		while(true) {
			String s = console.readLine("Select the operation you want to perform: \n" + 
				"'a' for addition, 's' for subtraction, 'm' for multiplication and 'd' for division: ");
			if (s.length() > 1 || (operation = operations.get(Character.toLowerCase(s.charAt(0)))) == null) {
				System.out.println("Not a valid selection.\n");
				continue;
			}

			int firstNum = 0, secondNum = 0;
			try {
				firstNum = Integer.parseInt(console.readLine("Enter the first number: "));
				secondNum = Integer.parseInt(console.readLine("Enter the second number: "));
			} catch(NumberFormatException e) {
				System.out.println("Not a valid number.\n");
				continue;
			}
			System.out.println("Result: " + operation.solve(firstNum, secondNum) + "\n\n");
		}
	}

	private static HashMap<Character, ArithmeticOperation> operations = new HashMap<Character, ArithmeticOperation>();

	static {
		operations.put('a', new Addition());
		operations.put('s', new Subtraction());
		operations.put('m', new Multiplication());
		operations.put('d', new Division());
	}
}

interface ArithmeticOperation {
	public int solve(int firstNum, int secondNum);
}

class Addition implements ArithmeticOperation {
	public int solve(int firstNum, int secondNum) {
		return firstNum + secondNum;
	}
}

class Subtraction implements ArithmeticOperation {
	public int solve(int firstNum, int secondNum) {
		return firstNum - secondNum;
	}
}

class Multiplication implements ArithmeticOperation {
	public int solve(int firstNum, int secondNum) {
		return firstNum * secondNum;
	}
}

class Division implements ArithmeticOperation {
	public int solve(int firstNum, int secondNum) {
		return firstNum / secondNum;
	}
}

Keep in mind however, usually you shouldn’t use OOP for such a simplistic handling routine, instead, you’d use a switch statement, but I did it this way to keep some of the design of your original program (in essence) and to teach you a bit about abstractness.[/quote]He specifically asked to keep the way his code was working, but fix his errors. If he wanted an arrogant jerk to give him new codes, he would have asked.

[quote=“DivineSouls, post:8, topic:355612”]David, I’ve tried working with the while method, I understand how it works, I don’t know what to insert in the condition, so if you could tell me it instead now lol, If i could just study it that would be great. Most appreciated.[/quote]You would create a new variable for the condition that is set to false, for example:

boolean found = false; while(!found) { //stuffz }And you would make it change ‘found’ to true once it recognized a proper input.

Read full topic

item.description:
@DivineSouls wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:6, topic:355612”][quote author=DivineSouls link=topic=452166.msg3314119#msg3314119 date=1282177364]
Rofl, ok, umm. let’s see. Can you give me a quick run down of how to loop? I don’t want to keep copying you so that i learn nothing. Just give me an idea on what the code is or what to do?
[/quote]

while (condition) { //DO STUFF WHILE CONDITION IS TRUE }

David, I’ve tried working with the while method, I understand how it works, I don’t know what to insert in the condition, so if you could tell me it instead now lol, If i could just study it that would be great. Most appreciated.

Abraham, the is probably a much better formated than what I made, but I’m not making this calculator so that I can give to other people, I’m making it so that I can get a better understanding of java scripting, I’ve just started about a week ago. What I’m trying to say is copying your entire class won’t help me much. I appreciate the help though.[/quote]

item.title: Can't figure it out. Help please
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

Don’t listen to Davidi2, he’s a clueless moron.

The thing with your current design is your use of OOP is kind of flawed. What you should have is the main class reading the next two numbers and then performing the required arithmetic operation, instead of simply pasting the same exact code in each one of the operation classes. Regardless, the operation handling can be setup in a map holding a character as the key (the operation character) and the selected handler as the value.

I wrote up an example that should be easy for you to understand of what the application should be:

import java.io.Console;
import java.util.HashMap;

class Main {

	public static void main(String[] args) {
		Console console = System.console();
		ArithmeticOperation operation = null;
		while(true) {
			String s = console.readLine("Select the operation you want to perform: \n" + 
				"'a' for addition, 's' for subtraction, 'm' for multiplication and 'd' for division: ");
			if (s.length() > 1 || (operation = operations.get(Character.toLowerCase(s.charAt(0)))) == null) {
				System.out.println("Not a valid selection.\n");
				continue;
			}

			int firstNum = 0, secondNum = 0;
			try {
				firstNum = Integer.parseInt(console.readLine("Enter the first number: "));
				secondNum = Integer.parseInt(console.readLine("Enter the second number: "));
			} catch(NumberFormatException e) {
				System.out.println("Not a valid number.\n");
				continue;
			}
			System.out.println("Result: " + operation.solve(firstNum, secondNum) + "\n\n");
		}
	}

	private static HashMap<Character, ArithmeticOperation> operations = new HashMap<Character, ArithmeticOperation>();

	static {
		operations.put('a', new Addition());
		operations.put('s', new Subtraction());
		operations.put('m', new Multiplication());
		operations.put('d', new Division());
	}
}

interface ArithmeticOperation {
	public int solve(int firstNum, int secondNum);
}

class Addition implements ArithmeticOperation {
	public int solve(int firstNum, int secondNum) {
		return firstNum + secondNum;
	}
}

class Subtraction implements ArithmeticOperation {
	public int solve(int firstNum, int secondNum) {
		return firstNum - secondNum;
	}
}

class Multiplication implements ArithmeticOperation {
	public int solve(int firstNum, int secondNum) {
		return firstNum * secondNum;
	}
}

class Division implements ArithmeticOperation {
	public int solve(int firstNum, int secondNum) {
		return firstNum / secondNum;
	}
}

Keep in mind however, usually you shouldn’t use OOP for such a simplistic handling routine, instead, you’d use a switch statement, but I did it this way to keep some of the design of your original program (in essence) and to teach you a bit about abstractness.

item.description:
@DivineSouls wrote:

I’m not sure if you can see the errors that well, but the first one is under the String input = input.nextLine();
I click on the help bar and it says this
“Multiple markers at this this line”
" - Duplicate local variable input"
" - The method nextLine() is undefined for the type String."

The second problem is in (info), They list the problem as…
“Info cannot be resolved to a variable”

item.source: Can't figure it out. Help please

item.title: Can't figure it out. Help please
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

You have no switch or anything. You just immediately are calling the addition class. If you notice, once you finish addition, it will go to subtraction, then multiplication, then division.

Try something like this:

[code=java]import java.util.Scanner;

public class MainClass {
public static void main(String args[]){
Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);
NameIdentifier nameIdentifierObject = new NameIdentifier ();
System.out.println(“Please enter your name:”);
String name = input.nextLine();
nameIdentifierObject.nameIdentifier (name);

            System.out.println(" ");
            System.out.print("What type of calculator do you want to use " + name );
            System.out.println("? (Type +, -, *, or /)");
            System.out.println("Or you can type \"info\" if you want information on this calculator.");
            System.out.print("+, -, *, /, or \"info\":");
            Addition additionObject = new Addition ();
            Subtraction subtractObject2 = new Subtraction ();
            Multiplication multiplicationObject3 = new Multiplication ();
            Division divisionObject4 = new Division ();
            Info infoObject5 = new Info ();
            String input = input.nextLine();

            if(input.equals("+")) {
              additionObject.Addition();
            }
           else if(input.equals("-")) {
              subtractObject2.Subtraction();
            }
           else if(input.equals("/")) {
              divisionObject4.Division();
            }
            else if(input.equals("*")) {
              multiplicationObject3.Multiplication();
            }                
            else if(input.toLowerCase().startsWith("info")) {
              infoObject5.Info(info);
            }  
            else {
              System.out.println("That is not a valid option!");
            }

}
}[/code]
Also, for all of your other classes, remove the “String add” part of the class.

There is a lot more I could do to this, like add a while loop so that it keeps going until you type a correct input, or adding catches for your ‘next___()’

Read full topic
item.source: Can't figure it out. Help please

item.title: Can't figure it out. Help please
item.dc:creator: @DivineSouls DivineSouls
item.description:
@DivineSouls wrote:

I’m some-what a beginner java programmer. I’m working on this calculator. I have the option that if you type either add, subtract, multiply, or divide that it will bring up the correct coding for that. The problem is, no matter what I type out of that 4, I always go to addition, than if I try again, subtraction. I understand it is going in order that I put the methods in. I don’t know how to split the methods up so that no matter what I type, it goes directly to that. I’ve tried making all the public voids inside the main class. that doesn’t work because than I can’t type anything in the calculator. I’ve tried placing all the classObjects into the actually class it belongs too, that doesn’t work.
Here’s the code to the Mainclass:

[code=javascript]import java.util.Scanner;

public class MainClass {
public static void main(String args[]){
Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);
NameIdentifier nameIdentifierObject = new NameIdentifier ();
System.out.println(“Please enter your name:”);
String name = input.nextLine();
nameIdentifierObject.nameIdentifier (name);

	System.out.println(" ");
	System.out.print("What type of calculator do you want to use " + name );
	System.out.println("? (Type add, subtract, multiply, or divide.)");
	System.out.println("Or you can type info if you want information on this calculator."); 
	
	Addition additionObject = new Addition ();
	String add = input.nextLine();
	additionObject.Addition(add); 
	
	Subtraction subtractObject2 = new Subtraction ();
	String subtract = input.nextLine();
	subtractObject2.Subtraction(subtract);
	
	Multiplication multiplicationObject3 = new Multiplication ();
	String multiply = input.nextLine(); 
	multiplicationObject3.Multiplication(multiply);
	
	Division divisionObject4 = new Division ();
	String divide = input.nextLine();
	divisionObject4.Division(divide);
	
	Info infoObject5 = new Info ();
	String info = input.nextLine();
	infoObject5.Info(info);

}
}[/code]

I understand for some of you more experienced programmers, this is a weird looking code for a calculator.
Here’s an example to one of the classes:

[code=javascript]import java.util.Scanner;

public class Addition {
public void Addition(String add){
Scanner one = new Scanner(System.in);
double fnum, snum, answer;

	System.out.println("Please enter your first Number:");
	fnum = one.nextDouble();
	System.out.println("Please enter your second number:");
	snum = one.nextDouble();
	System.out.println("The solution is:");
	answer = fnum + snum;
	System.out.println(answer);

}
}[/code]
subtraction, multiplication, and division are all similar to this.

Read full topic
